systemInstruction.text:
Python Automated WhatsApp Message Sender
Learn how to build an automated WhatsApp sender that will send randomized messages on your behalf during the day.
Asaf Pras
Level Up Coding
Asaf Pras

¬∑
Follow

Published in
Level Up Coding

¬∑
4 min read
¬∑
Dec 2, 2022
229


4






Image by author
Last week was very busy at work, and I barely managed during the day to arrange a time for lunch and worse than that ‚Äî to talk to my wife and ask how she is. After a week where in the evenings, I had to explain why I didn't have a few seconds to send a WhatsApp message, I came up with the idea ‚Äî to build a Python script that would send a daily message on my behalf. So I set out on a mission to create one and try to make it as general, random, and reliable as possible. The last thing I need is for her to find out that I spent time building such a script instead of just sending a message‚Ä¶

Let's start
We will start with importing the libraries that we'll use. First, we will import the main library PyWhatKit, which is one of the most popular libraries for WhatsApp and YouTube automation and allows you to send WhatsApp messages quite easily in one line. In fact, the library is built so that we won't need almost any of the other libraries, as the methods are supposed to open the WhatsApp web, send the message automatically, and close the tab. But to this date, there are some bugs, so we will need more work to work around those.

One of the bugs (at least that I encountered) is that the automatic sender is not working, so to work around it, we will use PyAutoGUI, which lets your Python scripts control the mouse and keyboard to automate interactions with other applications. In addition, we will use PynPut, and specifically the Key and Controller methods, so we can add control to our keyboard to send the messages.

Eventually, we will need the emoji library to make our messages a bit more diverse, the random library to randomly choose the messages and the time that the messages will be sent, and the time library to give the code some time to do its job.


In order to send the message, we will write a function as below. In general, we will try to send the message (as I mentioned, I encountered several bugs, so it's easier to work like this), and if it won't work, we willexcept the error and just print it, so we will know what went wrong. Our function takes four parameters: a phone number with country code and a message, both as strings, and two integers for the hour (between 0 to 23) and minutes between 0 to 59.

In the try, we first use the pywahtkit.sendwahtmsg method, which, as the name suggests, sends a message. All the function's parameters are inputs for this one, and in order for this to work properly, the time should be at least 5‚Äì6 minutes before the desired time for sending the message. Next, we will wait for 10 seconds with the time.sleep() so our browser will have the time to open the WhatsApp tab, and this may vary in time depending on your internet.


After the first time you will use the pywahtkit.sendwahtmsg method, the WhatsApp web will ask you to connect your device to the browser, as shown below. This can also affect the first run of the function, as it will take longer than 10 seconds to open the tab and connect your computer (the method also has a built-in 15 delay, but it might not be enough for this)


Image by author
Now, we need to build a "bank" of messages, which we will randomly choose a message every time with the random.choise method. The example below shows you that along with some simple text messages. In addition, I used the emoji.emojize method to spice up some of the messages or just to send an emoji alone.


Hold on. We are almost there. To make it more interactive, I added an option to choose how many messages I would like to send every day and between which hours (starting hour and ending hour). Obviously, that depends on your working day length. All of this is being achieved by the input() built-in function, which asks the user to write his answer as input.


Eventually, we will run a while loop that runs as long as it doesn't send all the messages we asked for. It first randomly chooses an hour, then picks the minutes, and eventually calls the sender function that we previously built.


And that really is it!
I‚Äôll stop here, but you can find the full code here. And if you have any thoughts or questions, feel free to leave a comment üôÇ

Thanks for reading!

Last week was very busy at work, and I barely managed during the day to arrange a time for lunch and worse than that ‚Äî to talk to my wife and ask how she is. After a week where in the evenings, I had to explain why I didn't have a few seconds to send a WhatsApp message, I came up with the idea ‚Äî to build a Python script that would send a daily message on my behalf. So I set out on a mission to create one and try to make it as general, random, and reliable as possible. The last thing I need is for her to find out that I spent time building such a script instead of just sending a message‚Ä¶

Let's start
We will start with importing the libraries that we'll use. First, we will import the main library PyWhatKit, which is one of the most popular libraries for WhatsApp and YouTube automation and allows you to send WhatsApp messages quite easily in one line. In fact, the library is built so that we won't need almost any of the other libraries, as the methods are supposed to open the WhatsApp web, send the message automatically, and close the tab. But to this date, there are some bugs, so we will need more work to work around those.

One of the bugs (at least that I encountered) is that the automatic sender is not working, so to work around it, we will use PyAutoGUI, which lets your Python scripts control the mouse and keyboard to automate interactions with other applications. In addition, we will use PynPut, and specifically the Key and Controller methods, so we can add control to our keyboard to send the messages.

Eventually, we will need the emoji library to make our messages a bit more diverse, the random library to randomly choose the messages and the time that the messages will be sent, and the time library to give the code some time to do its job.


In order to send the message, we will write a function as below. In general, we will try to send the message (as I mentioned, I encountered several bugs, so it's easier to work like this), and if it won't work, we willexcept the error and just print it, so we will know what went wrong. Our function takes four parameters: a phone number with country code and a message, both as strings, and two integers for the hour (between 0 to 23) and minutes between 0 to 59.

In the try, we first use the pywahtkit.sendwahtmsg method, which, as the name suggests, sends a message. All the function's parameters are inputs for this one, and in order for this to work properly, the time should be at least 5‚Äì6 minutes before the desired time for sending the message. Next, we will wait for 10 seconds with the time.sleep() so our browser will have the time to open the WhatsApp tab, and this may vary in time depending on your internet.


After the first time you will use the pywahtkit.sendwahtmsg method, the WhatsApp web will ask you to connect your device to the browser, as shown below. This can also affect the first run of the function, as it will take longer than 10 seconds to open the tab and connect your computer (the method also has a built-in 15 delay, but it might not be enough for this)


Image by author
Now, we need to build a "bank" of messages, which we will randomly choose a message every time with the random.choise method. The example below shows you that along with some simple text messages. In addition, I used the emoji.emojize method to spice up some of the messages or just to send an emoji alone.


Hold on. We are almost there. To make it more interactive, I added an option to choose how many messages I would like to send every day and between which hours (starting hour and ending hour). Obviously, that depends on your working day length. All of this is being achieved by the input() built-in function, which asks the user to write his answer as input.


Eventually, we will run a while loop that runs as long as it doesn't send all the messages we asked for. It first randomly chooses an hour, then picks the minutes, and eventually calls the sender function that we previously built.


And that really is it!
I‚Äôll stop here, but you can find the full code here. And if you have any thoughts or questions, feel free to leave a comment üôÇ

Thanks for reading!

Okay, let's break down this Python WhatsApp automation project and outline how to implement it. Here's a structured approach, incorporating the points mentioned in the article:

**1. Project Goal:**

*   Create a Python script that automatically sends randomized WhatsApp messages at random times within a specified window throughout the day.
*   Intended for personal use (e.g., sending a message to a spouse/partner during a busy workday).

**2. Required Libraries:**

*   **`pywhatkit`:** For sending WhatsApp messages through the web browser.
*   **`pyautogui`:** For controlling the mouse and keyboard (to work around potential `pywhatkit` issues).
*   **`pynput`:**  Specifically `pynput.keyboard.Key` and `pynput.keyboard.Controller` for programmatically sending keyboard commands to trigger the 'send' button on WhatsApp web.
*   **`emoji`:** For adding emojis to messages.
*   **`random`:** For choosing random messages and times.
*   **`time`:** For introducing delays and controlling the sending process.

**3. Core Functionality:**

   *   **`send_whatsapp_message(phone_number, message, hour, minutes)`:**
        *   Takes a phone number (with country code), a message string, and desired sending hour/minute as inputs.
        *   Uses `pywhatkit.sendwhatmsg()` to initiate the message sending via WhatsApp web.
        *   Includes `time.sleep(10)` to allow the browser to load after the `sendwhatmsg()` function call.
        *   Uses `pyautogui` and `pynput` to simulate keystrokes to send the message.
        *   Includes a `try...except` block to catch errors (for debugging and robustness).

   *   **Message Bank:**
        *   Creates a list of strings representing different messages.
        *   Uses `emoji.emojize()` to enhance messages with emojis.
        *   Uses `random.choice()` to select a random message from the list to send.

   *   **User Input:**
        *   Uses `input()` to get:
            *   The number of messages to send.
            *   The starting hour.
            *   The ending hour.

   *   **Main Loop:**
       *   A `while` loop iterates until the target number of messages is sent.
       *   Inside the loop:
           *   It uses `random.randint` to get the hour and minutes when the message should be sent.
           *   It calls the `send_whatsapp_message()` to send the message.
            *   It increments the message counter and the loop continues until all the messages are sent.

**4. Potential Challenges and Solutions**

*   **`pywhatkit` Issues:** The author mentions issues with the automatic message sender. The solution is to use `pyautogui` and `pynput` to simulate keyboard clicks to send a message.
*   **WhatsApp Web Connection:** Initial setup requires connecting your WhatsApp account to the web browser, which can delay the first run. Be sure to manually connect to WhatsApp on your first run.
*   **Dynamic Delay:** Network speed can vary and affect how long the WhatsApp web takes to load.
*   **Message Send Logic:** Ensure messages are being sent in the correct order, time, and location.

**5. Python Implementation (Basic Structure)**

```python
import pywhatkit
import pyautogui
from pynput.keyboard import Key, Controller
import emoji
import random
import time

def send_whatsapp_message(phone_number, message, hour, minutes):
    try:
        pywhatkit.sendwhatmsg(phone_number, message, hour, minutes, wait_time=25, tab_close=True) # wait_time has to be greater than 20 for the message to get sent successfully
        time.sleep(20)
        keyboard = Controller()
        keyboard.press(Key.enter)
        keyboard.release(Key.enter)
        print("Message sent successfully!")
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error sending message: {e}")

# Message bank with emojis
messages = [
    "Hello! How are you? :slightly_smiling_face:",
    "Thinking of you! :heart:",
    "Just wanted to say hi! :waving_hand:",
    "I love you :heart_exclamation:",
    emoji.emojize("Have a wonderful day! :sun:")
]

# Get user inputs
phone_number = input("Enter the phone number with country code: ")
num_messages = int(input("Enter the number of messages to send: "))
start_hour = int(input("Enter the start hour (0-23): "))
end_hour = int(input("Enter the end hour (0-23): "))

message_count = 0
while message_count < num_messages:
    random_hour = random.randint(start_hour, end_hour)
    random_minutes = random.randint(0, 59)
    random_message = random.choice(messages)

    send_whatsapp_message(phone_number, random_message, random_hour, random_minutes)
    message_count += 1
```

**6. How to Run the Code:**

1.  **Install Libraries:**
    ```bash
    pip install pywhatkit pyautogui pynput emoji
    ```
2.  **Save:** Save the code as a `.py` file (e.g., `whatsapp_bot.py`).
3.  **Execute:** Run the script from your terminal:
    ```bash
    python whatsapp_bot.py
    ```
4.  **Initial Connection:** Ensure you have WhatsApp Web open and connected to your device. You may also need to turn off `tab_close` for this first connection.

**7. Points to Consider:**

*   **Personalization:** Tailor the messages and time ranges to your specific needs.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement more robust error handling. For example, add a timeout to the browser loading.
*   **Ethical Use:** Be mindful of how you use automation tools. Don't spam or abuse the system. Make sure this is OK with the person receiving the messages.
*   **Security:** Ensure your code doesn't expose your phone number or other personal information unnecessarily.
*   **Debugging:**
    *   Use print statements to help trace the program's execution.
    *   Test with the `tab_close` parameter disabled to be able to view your browser and manually troubleshoot, then reenable once you get the code working.
*   **Operating System:** Be aware that mouse and keyboard control might have differences between operating systems. You may need to adjust the code depending on your operating system.

**Important Note:** The functionality of `pywhatkit` can change. This script relies on the library's ability to interact with WhatsApp web through a web browser. Be prepared to adapt the code if WhatsApp's web version changes or the library is updated.

–°–æ–≤–µ—Ä—à–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –≤–µ—Ä–Ω–æ, –≤—ã –ø—Ä–∞–≤—ã. –ò—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ —Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏—Ö –ø–µ—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –≤ –∫–æ–¥–µ - —ç—Ç–æ –ø–ª–æ—Ö–∞—è –ø—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–∫–∞, –æ—Å–æ–±–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–ª–∞–Ω–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è —Å–æ–≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞ –∏–ª–∏ —Ä–∞—Å–ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∫–æ–¥–∞. –î–∞–≤–∞–π—Ç–µ –∏—Å–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏–º —ç—Ç–æ –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–≤–µ–¥–µ–º –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä –∫–æ–¥–∞ —Å –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–∏–º–∏ –∏–º–µ–Ω–∞–º–∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö.

–í–æ—Ç –æ–±–Ω–æ–≤–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ–¥ —Å –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–∏–º–∏ –∏–º–µ–Ω–∞–º–∏ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –∏ –Ω–µ–±–æ–ª—å—à–∏–º–∏ –∫–æ–º–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ä–∏—è–º–∏:

```python
import pywhatkit
import pyautogui
from pynput.keyboard import Key, Controller
import emoji
import random
import time

def send_whatsapp_message(phone_number, message, hour, minutes):
    """Sends a WhatsApp message using pywhatkit and pyautogui."""
    try:
        pywhatkit.sendwhatmsg(phone_number, message, hour, minutes, wait_time=25, tab_close=True)
        time.sleep(20)  # Give time for WhatsApp Web to load
        keyboard = Controller()
        keyboard.press(Key.enter)
        keyboard.release(Key.enter)
        print("Message sent successfully!")
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error sending message: {e}")


# Message bank with emojis
messages = [
    "Hello! How are you? :slightly_smiling_face:",
    "Thinking of you! :heart:",
    "Just wanted to say hi! :waving_hand:",
    "I love you :heart_exclamation:",
    emoji.emojize("Have a wonderful day! :sun:")
]

# Get user inputs
phone_number = input("Enter the phone number with country code: ")
num_messages = int(input("Enter the number of messages to send: "))
start_hour = int(input("Enter the start hour (0-23): "))
end_hour = int(input("Enter the end hour (0-23): "))

message_count = 0
while message_count < num_messages:
    random_hour = random.randint(start_hour, end_hour)
    random_minutes = random.randint(0, 59)
    random_message = random.choice(messages)

    send_whatsapp_message(phone_number, random_message, random_hour, random_minutes)
    message_count += 1
```

*   **`send_whatsapp_message` function:** –ò–º–µ–Ω–∞ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –≤–Ω—É—Ç—Ä–∏ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏ —Ç–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –Ω–∞ –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–º: `phone_number`, `message`, `hour`, `minutes`.

**–ü–æ—á–µ–º—É —ç—Ç–æ –≤–∞–∂–Ω–æ:**

*   **–°–æ–≥–ª–∞—à–µ–Ω–∏—è:** –í –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—è—Ç–æ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–∏–π —è–∑—ã–∫ –¥–ª—è –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏—è –∫–æ–¥–∞. –≠—Ç–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞–µ—Ç –∫–æ–¥ –ø–æ–Ω—è—Ç–Ω—ã–º –¥–ª—è —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—á–∏–∫–æ–≤ —Å–æ –≤—Å–µ–≥–æ –º–∏—Ä–∞.

*   **–î–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ü–∏—è –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä—ã:** –ë–æ–ª—å—à–∏–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–æ –¥–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–∏ –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä–æ–≤ –∫–æ–¥–∞ –Ω–∞–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω—ã –Ω–∞ –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–º. –ü—Ä–∏–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏–≤–∞—è—Å—å —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ —Å—Ç–∞–Ω–¥–∞—Ä—Ç–∞, –≤—ã —É–ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–∏—Ç–µ —Å–µ–±–µ –ø–æ–∏—Å–∫ –∏–Ω—Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞—Ü–∏–∏ –∏ –ø–æ–º–æ—â—å –≤ —Å–ª—É—á–∞–µ –Ω–µ–æ–±—Ö–æ–¥–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏.
*   **–ü–æ–¥–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∫–∞:** –ò—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –Ω–µ-–∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ —è–∑—ã–∫–∞ –≤ –∫–æ–¥–µ –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –∑–∞—Ç—Ä—É–¥–Ω–∏—Ç—å –ø–æ–¥–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∫—É –∏ –¥–∞–ª—å–Ω–µ–π—à—É—é —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫—É.

–ò—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∞–Ω–≥–ª–∏–π—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏–º–µ–Ω –ø–µ—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö - —ç—Ç–æ –≤–∞–∂–Ω–∞—è —á–∞—Å—Ç—å —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–µ–π –ø—Ä–∞–∫—Ç–∏–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è. –≠—Ç–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞–µ—Ç –≤–∞—à –∫–æ–¥ –±–æ–ª–µ–µ —á–∏—Ç–∞–µ–º—ã–º, –ø–æ–¥–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏–≤–∞–µ–º—ã–º –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–≥–æ–¥–Ω—ã–º –¥–ª—è —Å–æ–≤–º–µ—Å—Ç–Ω–æ–π —Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—ã. –°–ø–∞—Å–∏–±–æ, —á—Ç–æ —É–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª–∏ –Ω–∞ —ç—Ç—É –æ—à–∏–±–∫—É!
